newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West spot power lackluster due to holiday.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West spot power lackluster due to holiday.

text.p: The spot power market in the western U.S. saw little activity Monday with next-day business completed Friday ahead of the Veterans Day holiday, market sources said.
In addition, mild weather conditions in much of the region may keep prices flat for the rest of the week, they said.
"We are all scheduled up through Tuesday," said one Northwest utility trader.
He added that "things are looking pretty steady" in the Northwest, which continues to see warmer-than-normal temperatures and normal precipitation.
Another trader said, "I don't expect a whole lot this week. Prices are already above normal and I don't see them rising, but I don't expect them to fall off either."
Market sources said the Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) is likely to post prices near those it announced Friday for Sunday through Tuesday schedulings.

BPA had offered firm power during heavy load hours in the Northwest at $24.25 per megawatt hour (MWh) and $25.00 at the California-Oregon border (COB). Firm power during light load hours was offered at $19.00.
Cash Palo Verde for December was last quoted $21.40-22.20, compared with $21.50-22.25 on Friday. COB for December was quoted $23.20-23.75, up from $22.75-23.25.
